Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Pervasive Spectrum Sharing for Public Safety
Award.AbstractNarration:
Next-generation public safety communication (PSC) systems must deliver high-capacity wireless services to public safety personnel and users in disaster-affected areas, with little reliance on infrastructure. Remarkably, modern-day PSC systems have yet to catch up with the past decade's wireless revolution, as they still rely on technologies of yesteryears that fall short on delivering high-speed wireless access. Indeed, coping with the foreseen stringent service requirements in future PSC systems mandates major innovations that can increase spectral efficiency. This, in turn, requires tackling multidisciplinary challenges: 1) developing incentive mechanisms for government agencies, providers, and users to share their precious spectrum resources; 2) dynamically managing interdependent spectrum markets; and 3) efficiently modeling and operating sustainable communication protocols that can function with little infrastructure support. This project brings together researchers in wireless communications and networking, game theory, mathematics, and public safety administration to address these challenges and boost the efficiency of PSC by introducing a novel framework that provides the necessary analytical tools for modeling, designing, analyzing, and operating large-scale spectrum sharing in disaster and emergency situations.

The overarching scientific merit of this research is to initiate the much-needed leap towards a more open, highly participatory, and pervasive sharing of the wireless spectrum for PSC. This project offers an array of spectrum sharing innovations: 1) new economic approaches and PSC mechanisms that provide incentives for government agencies, providers, and end-users, to effectively subsidize the scarce radio spectrum and facilitate novel public safety and spectrum allocation policies; 2) a foundational framework that tightly integrates tools from game theory and auction theory for enabling a dynamic operation of co-existing spectrum sharing markets with multi-hop capabilities; 3) novel realistic models for characterizing wireless channels, traffic, topology, user behavior, and mobility in PSC; and 4) effective and accelerated transition of theoretical results to practice via a new PSC testbed for extensive validation and close collaboration with several major industry partners and local public safety agencies. In a nutshell, the project provides a new generation of PSC systems and protocols that expedite the response to disasters, save lives, and reduce economic costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the fall and spring semesters of academic years 2014/2015, 2015/2016, and 2016/2017, Dr. Naim Kapucu partnered with Florida International University, Virginia Tech, and University of Nevada-Reno for a National Science Foundation project of Collaborative Research: Pervasive Spectrum Sharing for Public Safety. Although there were five overarching goals of the project, Dr. Kapucu and his team of doctoral students focused on investigating key policies and regulations concerning wireless communication and spectrum sharing. Moreover, they researched these aspects from the lens of emergency and crisis management and public safety. The emphasis was on communication within a networked environment of disaster response operations for effective communication for disaster resilience and public safety. Their research would assist the other partnering institutions in their goals of creating a novel, hierarchical, non-cooperative game-theoretic approach to create visuals on how fostering the sharing of radio spectrum can be accomplished through the use of regulatory power.

 

The study findings suggest that, effective and beneficial regulation and policies can be created with to involve stakeholders and incentive them to share spectrum. Focusing on today’s public safety system, we know communication failures can lead to catastrophic consequences. In the United States, it is estimated more than 50,000 state and local public safety agencies currently exist with fewer than 50 users mobilizing radio systems for wireless communication while employing approximately 1.1 million first responders. Therefore, effective performance of this complex communication system hinges on availability of high capacity wireless services, which depends on spectrum availability. Through the research, some key challenges surfaced as to how today’s scarce spectrum is being underutilized and why wireless technology from the past decades is unable to cope with current demands. These challenges include:

 

  • Lack of an innovatively formed, cost-effective implementation of the independent spectrum markets with diverse wireless resources,
  • Limited policies and procedures to regulate stakeholders for spectrum sharing and management, and
  • Need for realistic modeling and efficient operation of communication infrastructure within disaster-affected environments.

 

Although these challenges exist, the United States is in the process of implementing a national public safety communication system as it is theorized to enhance interoperability, spectrum efficiency, dependability and fault tolerance, advanced capabilities, security, and cost effectiveness. However, the main question is how can policy-makers manage and connect local based systems while bridging into the commercial market to assist in production, innovation, and competitive pricing?

 

To answer this main question and assist in accomplishing the overarching goals of the project, the researchers from UCF compiled key resources to develop the dialogue and assist with future analysis. Once these documents were identified, a systematic document analysis focusing on key words of “wireless communication, spectrum sharing and interoperability.” Documents reviewed included: FEMA’s National Planning Framework (Protection, Prevention, Mitigation, Response, Recovery), National Emergency Communication Plan (NECP), DHS 2016 National Emergency Communication Plan (NECP), Preparedness Report and 2012 GAO Spectrum Sharing Report. In addition, the 2015 Hearing on National Wireless Public Safety Network was analyzed. These findings were published in an article for the Journal of Emergency Management and a portion of the research formulated the foundation for publication in Frontiers in Communication, section on Disaster Communication. Moreover, key findings were presented at the Association for Public Policy Analysis and Management 2015 annual conference.

 

Once the foundation was created, the researchers focused on the current policy and regulatory context of spectrum and wireless communication for public safety. Due to the vast number of fragmented, independent public safety wireless communication systems, providing all localities, states, and federal entities with compatible devices and infrastructure will cost billions in taxpayer money, yet these technological infrastructures may become out-of-date within a few years due to inevitable advancements.

 

With the limited resources referencing interoperability, the researchers honed on coordination and collaboration as an imminent need seeing as how wireless communication requires collaboration between and within emergency management and public safety agencies and hinges on creation of a common language, policies and procedures. This avenue of research led to a second publication in the Journal of Emergency Management and a presentation at the 2016 American Society for Public Administration annual conference. Lastly, discussion on spectrum sharing in the context of public safety is nonexistent and left to outside research, which emphasizes the need for more federal involvement in terms of allocation and sharing regulations and incentives. We reported these insights in a submission to the journal Risk, Hazards, & Crisis in Public Policy, as well as presented them at the 2017 Public Management Research Conference in Washington, D.C. Additional papers are either under review and will be presented at academic conferences from this project.
